text:
Lithium ion batteries have become a ubiquitous
part of the digital revolution, but not without

a serious setback – they keep spontaneously
exploding, and consumers are getting sick
of it.

So, what’s the underlying issue, and what
the heck is science doing to fix it?

Today we’re talking battery fires folks,
and the future that’s being charged up in
the labs.

Before we get to the explosions, let’s recap
how batteries work.

Electricity is all about the flow of electrons
through a conductive material, and a battery
is a way of storing and controlling this flow.

These are the four basic parts of a battery
(show cathode, anode, electrolyte, and a circuit).

To keep it simple, the electrons flow from
the negative anode and around to the positively
charged cathode.

The electrolyte is usually a fluid between
the two.

For more on how batteries work, click on that
thing.

Lithium is a current standard for cathodes:
It allows for the easy transfer of electrons

and it’s lightweight making for a more portable
battery pack.

Li batteries usually employ lithium cobalt
oxide as the cathode, graphite as an anode,

and a lithium salt bathed in a mixture of
one or more alkyl carbonates as the electrolyte.

Even though these materials have helped make
portable, relatively efficient batteries,
they don’t come without setbacks.

Let’s not forget that lithium is an alkali
metal meaning it’s highly reactive - pure

lithium is often kept in oil so it doesn’t
corrode immediately in air.

Not to mention, organic electrolytes like
dimethyl carbonate are extremely combustible.

The lithium and the electrolyte are two pieces
of the flaming hot chemical puzzle known as
thermal runaway.

Thermal runaway is what happens when a battery
cell spontaneously explodes.

There’s a few different reasons why this
happens:

The overcharging of a battery, overheating,
physical damage, or faulty manufacturing resulting
in an electrical short.

This is what happened to those blow-uppy Galaxy
Sevens.

To keep it simple, anything that can lead
to a rapid increase in heat can cause a problem.

When multiple chemical reactions cause superheating,
the lithium cobalt oxide begins to release

oxygen, which can react with the alkyl carbonate
and even the leftover cobalt oxide.

Also during overcharging, that alkyl carbonate
can break down, creating carbon dioxide gas

that will expand outward and burst the electrolyte
open, exposing its flammable contents.

In laboratory studies on thermal runaway two
flammable gasses, hydrogen and methane have

also been detected as well as temperatures
as high as 850°C - that’s is pretty darn
hot!

And you definitely don’t want that kind
of heat by your face.

In 2013, a teenager received 3rd degree burns
due to the thermal runaway of a smartphone
battery.

This has become common enough that the FAA
has recently banned certain smartphones models
from planes.

The National Transportation Safety Board has
even issued alerts regarding lithium batteries

as air cargo, based on investigations from
a plane crash in 2011.

Needless to say it’s not a good sign when
a factory that makes these batteries goes
up in flames.

Which is exactly what happened earlier this
year.
So wait a minute.

Why hasn’t this problem been scienced out
of existence yet?

Well wouldn’t you know, it looks like the
future of lithium ion batteries might rest

in the hands of one of its co-inventors, John
Goodenough.

He recently lead a group of researchers on
a quest for a better battery.

They came out with one that is noncombustible,
lasts longer and carries three times the energy
density of current forms of batteries.

Goodenough’s team believes their newest
innovation is safer because the electrolyte

is solid glass which cuts out the flammable
alkyl carbonate.

It’s better at storing energy, would charge
and discharge faster, and could be physically
shaped into more options.

And that’s just one of many new battery
designs in the works.

So things are looking good for lithium ion
batteries.

We may be able to look forward to a day when
exploding batteries are blasts that stay in
the past.

If you have any questions about the chemistry
of your gadgets, go ahead and post them down
there in the comments for us.

Don’t forget to hit thumbs up and subscribe
on the way out and we’ll see you again soon.
